text: What is said to be happening to an object if its position is changing with respect to its surroundings?
explanation: If an object's position changes relative to its surroundings over time, it is described as being in motion. This is the fundamental definition of motion.

text: Which of the following is an example of motion that is often perceived indirectly rather than by direct observation of the moving substance itself?

options.text: A car driving on a road
A ball thrown in the air
The movement of air (wind) causing leaves to rustle

explanation: Sometimes we cannot see the motion of an object directly. For example, the movement of air (wind or breeze) is often inferred by observing the motion of other objects it affects, such as leaves rustling or flags waving.

text: If you are travelling in a bus, and the person sitting next to you is also in the bus, what can you say about their motion relative to you?

options.text: Their motion depends on the bus's speed.
Their motion depends on the bus's direction.

explanation: Motion is a relative concept. If the position of the person next to you is not changing with respect to you (your immediate surroundings from your perspective within the bus), they are at rest relative to you, even though both of you are in motion relative to the ground.

text: What is defined as the length of the actual path travelled by an object in motion from one point to another?
explanation: Distance is a scalar quantity that refers to 'how much ground an object has covered' during its motion. It is the total length of the path travelled.

text: Displacement is defined as the minimum distance between which two points?

options.text: Any two points along the path
The point of highest speed and lowest speed
The point of maximum acceleration and minimum acceleration

explanation: Displacement is a vector quantity defined as the shortest straight-line distance between an object's initial (starting) position and its final (finishing) position, including the direction from start to finish.

text: An athlete runs from point A to point B, a distance of 100m east, then turns around and runs 30m west to point C. What is the athlete's displacement from point A?
explanation: Displacement is the net change in position from the starting point. The athlete moves 100m East (+100m) and then 30m West (-30m). The net displacement is +100m - 30m = +70m, which is 70m East.

text: If an object's displacement is zero, what can be said about the actual distance traversed by it?

options.text: The actual distance must also be zero.
The actual distance must be non-zero.
The actual distance may or may not be zero.
The object must have been at rest.

explanation: If an object returns to its starting point, its displacement is zero. However, the distance travelled (the actual path length) would be non-zero. If the object never moved, both distance and displacement would be zero. Therefore, zero displacement does not necessarily mean zero distance.

text: Which of the following quantities is a vector quantity, meaning it has both magnitude and direction?
explanation: Velocity is a vector quantity because it specifies both the speed of an object and its direction of motion. Distance, speed, and time are scalar quantities, having only magnitude.

text: What is the SI unit of speed?
explanation: The SI (International System of Units) unit for speed, which is distance divided by time, is meters per second (m/s).

text: What is the CGS unit of velocity?
explanation: In the CGS (Centimeter-Gram-Second) system of units, the unit for velocity (displacement divided by time) is centimeters per second (cm/s).

text: Velocity is defined as the rate of change of displacement. This means it incorporates both speed and:
explanation: Velocity is displacement (which has direction) per unit time. It describes how fast an object is moving and in what direction it is moving. So, velocity incorporates both speed (magnitude of velocity) and direction.

text: If a car is moving with constant speed along a straight road, its velocity will:

options.text: Change due to change in speed
Change due to change in direction
Change due to both speed and direction change

explanation: Velocity has both magnitude (speed) and direction. If the speed is constant and the direction is also constant (straight road), then the velocity remains constant.

text: A car is moving at a constant speed of 60 km/h while navigating a circular turn. What happens to its velocity?

options.text: Velocity will change due to change in speed.
Velocity will change due to change in direction.
Velocity will change due to change in both speed and direction.

explanation: Velocity is a vector quantity, meaning it has both magnitude (speed) and direction. Even if the speed is constant (60 km/h), if the direction of motion changes (as in a circular turn), the velocity changes.

text: Which early scientist is credited with formalizing the measurement of speed as the ratio of distance to time?
explanation: Galileo Galilei was a pioneer in the quantitative study of motion and is credited with being among the first to measure speed by considering the relationship between distance travelled and the time taken.

text: If you observe a lightning flash and then hear the thunder 5 seconds later, knowing the speed of sound in air is approximately 340 m/s, how can you estimate the distance to the lightning strike?

options.text: Distance = Speed of sound / Time delay
Distance = Time delay / Speed of sound
Distance = Speed of sound × Time delay
Distance = Speed of sound + Time delay

explanation: The speed of light is much greater than the speed of sound, so the lightning flash is seen almost instantly. The sound of thunder travels at approximately 340 m/s. The distance to the strike can be estimated by multiplying the speed of sound by the time delay between seeing the flash and hearing the thunder (Distance = Speed × Time). In this case, 340 m/s × 5 s = 1700 m.

text: When is an object said to be moving with uniform speed?

options.text: When it covers unequal distances in equal time intervals.
When it covers equal distances in unequal time intervals.
When it covers equal distances in equal time intervals.
When its velocity changes at a constant rate.

explanation: An object is said to be moving with uniform speed if it travels equal distances in equal intervals of time, no matter how small these intervals may be.

text: Non-uniform speed is observed when an object covers:

options.text: Equal distances in equal time intervals.
Unequal distances in equal time intervals.
Equal distances in unequal time intervals.
Constant speed in a non-linear path.

explanation: An object is said to be moving with non-uniform speed if it travels unequal distances in equal intervals of time. An example is a car moving in city traffic.

text: What is defined as the rate of change of velocity?
explanation: Acceleration is a vector quantity defined as the rate at which an object's velocity changes over time. This change can be in speed, direction, or both.

text: If the initial velocity of an object is 'u' and it changes to final velocity 'v' in time 't', the formula for acceleration 'a' is:
explanation: Acceleration is the change in velocity (final velocity 'v' minus initial velocity 'u') divided by the time 't' taken for that change. So, the formula is a = (v-u)/t.

text: When is an object said to be in uniformly accelerated motion?

options.text: If its velocity changes by unequal amounts in equal time intervals.
If its speed is constant but direction changes.
If its velocity changes by equal amounts in equal time intervals.

explanation: Uniformly accelerated motion occurs when the velocity of an object changes by equal amounts in equal intervals of time. This means the acceleration is constant.

text: What is negative acceleration also called?
explanation: Negative acceleration, where the acceleration is in the opposite direction to the velocity (causing the object to slow down if moving in the positive direction), is also commonly called deceleration or retardation.

text: If the velocity of an object does not change with time, what is its acceleration?
explanation: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity. If the velocity does not change (i.e., it is constant in both magnitude and direction), then the change in velocity is zero, and therefore the acceleration is zero.

text: For a uniformly accelerated motion, what is the shape of the velocity-time graph?

options.text: A straight line with a non-zero slope

explanation: In uniformly accelerated motion, the velocity changes by equal amounts in equal time intervals. This constant rate of change of velocity results in a velocity-time graph that is a straight line with a constant, non-zero slope. The slope itself represents the constant acceleration.

text: What does the area under the velocity-time graph represent?

options.text: Displacement (or distance travelled in a specific direction)

explanation: The area enclosed between the velocity-time graph and the time axis gives the magnitude of the displacement of the object during that time interval. If motion is in one direction, this also equals distance.

text: Which of Newton's equations of motion relates displacement (s), initial velocity (u), time (t), and uniform acceleration (a)?
explanation: The second equation of motion, s = ut + 1/2 at^2, describes the displacement 's' of an object in terms of its initial velocity 'u', the time 't' for which it moves, and its constant acceleration 'a'.

text: Which of Newton's equations of motion relates final velocity (v), initial velocity (u), uniform acceleration (a), and displacement (s)?
explanation: The third equation of motion, v^2 = u^2 + 2as, provides a relationship between the final velocity 'v', initial velocity 'u', constant acceleration 'a', and displacement 's', without directly involving time.

text: The rate of change of velocity is also described graphically. If velocity is plotted on the Y-axis and time on the X-axis, what property of the graph represents acceleration?
explanation: Acceleration is defined as the change in velocity divided by the change in time (Δv/Δt). On a velocity-time graph, this ratio (rise over run) corresponds to the slope of the line or curve.

text: In uniform circular motion, the speed of the object is constant, but its velocity changes. Why is the velocity changing?

options.text: Due to change in direction of motion
Due to change in both speed and direction

explanation: Velocity is a vector quantity, possessing both magnitude (speed) and direction. In uniform circular motion, the speed remains constant, but the direction of the object's motion is continuously changing as it moves along the circular path. This change in direction means the velocity is changing.

text: What is the direction of velocity of an object moving in uniform circular motion at any given point on its path?

options.text: Towards the center of the circle
Away from the center of the circle
Tangential to the circular path at that point
Perpendicular to the tangent and towards the center

explanation: The instantaneous velocity of an object in uniform circular motion is always directed along the tangent to the circular path at that specific point. If the force causing the circular motion were to disappear, the object would fly off along this tangent.

text: In uniform circular motion, is the motion accelerated or non-accelerated?

options.text: Non-accelerated, because the speed is constant.
Accelerated, because the direction of velocity is constantly changing.
Non-accelerated, because the net force is zero.
Accelerated, but only if the speed is also changing.

explanation: Uniform circular motion is an example of accelerated motion. Even though the speed (magnitude of velocity) is constant, the direction of the velocity vector is continuously changing. Since acceleration is the rate of change of velocity, a change in direction implies acceleration (known as centripetal acceleration).

text: Newton's first law of motion is also known as the law of:
explanation: Newton's first law of motion describes the concept of inertia, which is the tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion (whether at rest or moving with constant velocity).

text: What property does Newton's first law explain, stating an object's inability to change its state of motion on its own?
explanation: Newton's first law of motion explains the phenomenon of inertia. Inertia is the inherent property of an object that makes it resist any change in its state of rest or of uniform motion along a straight line.

text: According to Newton's First Law, if an object is moving with uniform motion along a straight line, what can be said about the external unbalanced force acting on it?

options.text: An unbalanced force is acting in the direction of motion.
An unbalanced force is acting opposite to the direction of motion.
The net external unbalanced force is zero.
There are no forces acting on the object.

explanation: Newton's First Law states that an object continues in its state of rest or of uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by an external unbalanced force. This implies that if it's already in uniform motion, the net external unbalanced force acting on it must be zero. Forces might be present, but they balance each other out.

text: In a tug-of-war, when does the center of the rope remain static (not move)?

options.text: When the forces applied by both sides are unequal.
When the forces applied by both sides are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction (balanced).
When a net force is applied in the direction of the greater force.
Only when no forces are applied at all.

explanation: In a tug-of-war, the center of the rope remains static as long as the forces applied by both sides are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction. These are called balanced forces, and they result in no change in the state of motion of the rope's center.

text: Momentum (P) is defined as the product of which two quantities?
explanation: Momentum (P) of an object is a physical quantity defined as the product of its mass (m) and its velocity (v). The formula is P = mv.

text: What type of physical quantity is momentum?
explanation: Momentum is a vector quantity. This is because it is the product of mass (a scalar) and velocity (a vector). Therefore, momentum has both magnitude and direction, the same as velocity.

text: What is the SI unit of momentum?
explanation: The SI unit of momentum is derived from its definition (mass × velocity). Mass is in kilograms (kg) and velocity is in meters per second (m/s) in the SI system. Thus, the SI unit of momentum is kg m/s. Note that Newton-second (N s) is also an equivalent unit for momentum (and impulse).

text: According to Newton's second law of motion, the rate of change of momentum of an object is proportional to what?

options.text: The time interval of the change

explanation: Newton's second law of motion states that the rate of change of an object's momentum is directly proportional to the net (unbalanced) force applied to it and occurs in the direction of the force.

text: In the common form of Newton's Second Law, F = ma, the proportionality constant 'k' (from F ∝ ma) is taken as 1. What does this imply about the definition of the unit of force?

options.text: Force is independent of mass and acceleration.
The unit of force is defined such that k becomes 1.
Mass and acceleration are always equal.
The constant 'k' varies with the system of units.

explanation: Newton's second law is F ∝ ma, or F = kma. The units of force (like the Newton in SI) are defined in such a way that the constant of proportionality 'k' becomes equal to 1. For example, 1 Newton is the force that gives a 1 kg mass an acceleration of 1 m/s².

text: If the same net force is applied to two different objects for the same duration of time, which of the following quantities will be the same for both objects?
explanation: According to Newton's second law, Force = Rate of change of momentum (Δp/Δt). Therefore, Δp = Force × Δt. If the same force (F) acts for the same time interval (Δt) on different objects, the change in momentum (Δp), also known as impulse, will be the same for all objects. Their accelerations and changes in velocity would differ if their masses are different.

text: What fundamental concept, describing how forces occur in nature, is encapsulated by Newton's Third Law of Motion?

options.text: Inertia: objects resist changes in motion.
Momentum: the product of mass and velocity.
Forces always occur in pairs as a reciprocal action between two objects.

explanation: Newton's Third Law states that forces in nature always occur in pairs. For every action force, there is an equal and opposite reaction force. Force is a reciprocal interaction between two objects.

text: According to Newton's Third Law, what is the relationship between an action force and its reaction force?

options.text: They are equal in magnitude and in the same direction.
They are unequal in magnitude and in opposite directions.
They are equal in magnitude and in opposite directions.
They are unequal in magnitude and in the same direction.

explanation: Newton's Third Law of Motion states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. This means the action force and the reaction force are always equal in magnitude but act in opposite directions.

text: When do action and reaction forces act?

options.text: At different times, action first then reaction.
Only when the net force is unbalanced.

explanation: A key characteristic of action and reaction forces, as described by Newton's Third Law, is that they act simultaneously. There is no time delay between the action and the reaction.

text: A key characteristic of action and reaction forces is that they act on:

options.text: The same object, canceling each other out.
Different objects, and therefore do not cancel each other out with respect to a single object's motion.
The same object, reinforcing each other.
Different objects, but they still cancel each other out globally.

explanation: Action and reaction forces always act on different objects. Because they act on different objects, they cannot cancel each other's effect on the motion of a single object. For example, if you push a wall (action on wall), the wall pushes you (reaction on you).

text: Which of the following is a common example illustrating Newton's Third Law of Motion?

options.text: A ball rolling to a stop due to friction.
A gun recoiling backward when a bullet is fired forward.
An object remaining at rest unless a force acts on it.
A planet orbiting the Sun due to gravity.

explanation: When a gun fires a bullet, the gun exerts a forward force on the bullet (action). Simultaneously, the bullet exerts an equal and opposite backward force on the gun (reaction), causing the gun to recoil. This is a direct application of Newton's Third Law.

text: The Law of Conservation of Momentum states that if no external force acts on a system of two interacting objects, their total momentum:
explanation: The Law of Conservation of Momentum states that in an isolated system (where no net external force acts), the total momentum of the system remains constant, regardless of the interactions (like collisions) occurring within the system.

text: In a collision between two objects, according to the Law of Conservation of Momentum (assuming no external forces), the total momentum before the collision is equal to:

options.text: The momentum of the first object after collision.
The momentum of the second object after collision.
The difference in momenta after collision.
The total momentum after the collision.

explanation: The Law of Conservation of Momentum specifically states that when two objects collide in an isolated system, their total momentum before the collision is equal to their total momentum after the collision.

text: The backward motion of a gun after firing a bullet is called:
explanation: Recoil is the term used to describe the backward momentum or 'kick' experienced by a gun when it fires a projectile, such as a bullet. This phenomenon is a direct consequence of Newton's Third Law and the conservation of momentum.

text: In the gun recoil example, why is the velocity of the gun much smaller than the velocity of the bullet, even though the momenta are equal and opposite?

options.text: Because the gun has less momentum.
Because the bullet has less momentum.
Because the mass of the gun is much higher than the mass of the bullet.
Because the force on the gun is smaller than the force on the bullet.

explanation: Due to conservation of momentum, the magnitude of the bullet's forward momentum (mass_bullet × velocity_bullet) is equal to the magnitude of the gun's backward momentum (mass_gun × velocity_gun). Since the mass of the gun is significantly larger than the mass of the bullet, its recoil velocity must be proportionally smaller to keep the momentum product equal.

text: When an object is in uniform motion along a straight line, its average velocity over any time interval is:

options.text: Always greater than its instantaneous speed.
Always less than its instantaneous speed.
Equal to its instantaneous velocity (and its speed).

explanation: In uniform motion along a straight line, the velocity is constant (both speed and direction do not change). Therefore, the instantaneous velocity at any point is the same. The average velocity, calculated as total displacement divided by total time, will also be equal to this constant instantaneous velocity. Since direction is constant, speed is equal to the magnitude of velocity.

text: A stone lying on a hill is an example of an object that is primarily considered to be:

options.text: In motion relative to the Sun
At rest relative to the hill

explanation: While the stone is in motion relative to distant objects like the Sun (due to Earth's rotation and orbit), in the context of local observation and typical physics problems, a stone lying on a hill is considered at rest relative to its immediate surroundings (the hill). Its position is not changing with respect to the hill.

text: An object moves in a complete circle, starting from point A and returning to point A. What is its total displacement?

options.text: Equal to the circumference of the circle.
Equal to the radius of the circle.
Twice the radius of the circle.

explanation: Displacement is the shortest straight-line distance between the initial and final positions, including direction. If an object completes a full circle and returns to its starting point, its initial and final positions are identical. Therefore, the net displacement is zero.

text: A car travels half the circumference of a circular track of radius 100m. What is the distance it has travelled? (Use π ≈ 3.14)
explanation: The circumference of a full circular track is given by C = 2πr. If the car travels half the circumference, the distance travelled is (1/2) × 2πr = πr. Given radius r = 100m and π ≈ 3.14, the distance = 3.14 × 100m = 314m.

text: The Earth revolves around the Sun in a nearly circular orbit. What is the approximate speed of the Earth in its orbit, a value often cited in physics?
explanation: The Earth orbits the Sun at a very high average speed. A commonly cited approximate value for this orbital speed is about 29,770 meters per second, which is roughly 30 kilometers per second.

text: What type of motion is described as covering unequal distances in equal time intervals?
explanation: If an object covers unequal distances in equal intervals of time, its speed is not constant. This type of motion is referred to as non-uniform speed.

text: What does a straight line graph in a distance-time graph indicate, assuming the line is not horizontal or vertical?
explanation: An object in uniform motion (constant speed in a straight line) covers equal distances in equal time intervals. This results in a distance-time graph that is a straight line with a constant slope. The slope of this line represents the uniform speed.

text: What does the slope of a distance-time graph indicate?

options.text: Speed (or magnitude of velocity if motion is in one direction)

explanation: The slope of a distance-time graph is calculated as the change in distance divided by the change in time (Δd/Δt). This ratio represents the speed of the object. If the graph plots displacement vs. time, the slope represents velocity.

text: What is the general shape of a distance-time graph for an object moving with non-uniform speed (e.g., accelerating or decelerating)?

options.text: A straight line with a non-zero slope

explanation: For non-uniform motion, where the speed is changing, the object covers unequal distances in equal time intervals. This means the slope of the distance-time graph is not constant, resulting in a curved line. For example, if an object is accelerating, the distance covered per unit time increases, leading to an upward-curving line.

text: If an object is moving with uniform velocity, what is the shape of its velocity-time graph?

options.text: A straight line with a positive slope
A horizontal line parallel to the time axis
A vertical line parallel to the velocity axis

explanation: Uniform velocity means the velocity is constant (both speed and direction are unchanged). On a velocity-time graph, a constant velocity is represented by a horizontal straight line parallel to the time axis, indicating that the velocity value does not change over time.

text: If an object's initial velocity is zero and it undergoes uniform acceleration, what is the relationship between its final velocity (v) and time (t)?

options.text: v is inversely proportional to t
v is directly proportional to t

explanation: The first equation of motion is v = u + at. If the initial velocity u = 0 (starts from rest), then v = at. Since acceleration 'a' is uniform (constant), the final velocity 'v' is directly proportional to the time 't'.

text: If an object starts from rest and moves with uniform acceleration 'a', the distance 's' covered in time 't' is given by which equation?
explanation: The second equation of motion is s = ut + 1/2 at^2. If the object starts from rest, its initial velocity u = 0. Substituting u=0 into the equation gives s = (0)t + 1/2 at^2, which simplifies to s = 1/2 at^2.

text: What is the displacement of an object in uniform circular motion after completing half a circle of radius 'r'?
explanation: Displacement is the shortest straight-line distance between the initial and final positions. After completing half a circle, the object is at a point diametrically opposite to its starting point. The straight-line distance between these two points is the diameter of the circle, which is 2r.

text: In uniform circular motion, the speed is calculated using the circumference and time period. What formula gives the speed (v) of an object moving in a circle of radius 'r' if it completes one revolution in time 'T' (period)?
explanation: In one complete revolution, the distance travelled by the object is the circumference of the circle, which is 2πr. If the time taken for one revolution (the period) is T, then the speed v = Distance/Time = 2πr/T.

text: If an object's velocity is changing in either magnitude or direction, or both, what is it said to be undergoing?
explanation: Acceleration is defined as the rate of change of velocity. Since velocity is a vector with both magnitude (speed) and direction, a change in either speed, or direction, or both, constitutes a change in velocity, and thus the object is undergoing accelerated motion.

text: According to Newton's First Law, a static object will remain at rest unless acted upon by:
explanation: Newton's First Law of Motion states that an object at rest will remain at rest, and an object in motion will continue in motion with constant velocity, unless it is acted upon by a net external unbalanced force.

text: Why does a book placed on a table not move on its own, even though the force of gravity is acting downwards on it?

options.text: Because the net force on the book is zero, as the table exerts an equal upward normal force.
Because gravity is a balanced force by itself.
Because the book has zero inertia.
Because there are no other horizontal forces acting on the book.

explanation: A book on a table has gravity pulling it down. However, the table exerts an equal and opposite upward force (normal force) on the book. These two forces balance each other, resulting in a net force of zero on the book. According to Newton's First Law, if the net force is zero, an object at rest (like the book) will remain at rest.

text: Momentum is described as a property related to both mass and velocity that quantifies the 'quantity of motion' an object possesses and affects the outcome of collisions. This concept helps understand:

options.text: The impact an object can have when it strikes another.
The thermal energy of an object.

explanation: Momentum (P=mv) is a measure of an object's motion that combines its mass and velocity. A larger momentum implies a greater 'quantity of motion', meaning it is harder to stop or change its motion, and it will have a greater impact in a collision.

text: A force of 1 Newton applied to an object of mass 1 kg will cause an acceleration of:
explanation: The Newton (N) is the SI unit of force. It is defined such that 1 Newton is the force required to give a mass of 1 kilogram an acceleration of 1 meter per second squared (1 m/s²). This definition comes directly from Newton's Second Law, F=ma.

text: What is the CGS unit of force?
explanation: In the CGS (Centimeter-Gram-Second) system of units, the unit of force is the dyne. One dyne is the force required to give a mass of 1 gram an acceleration of 1 centimeter per second squared.

text: The force required to cause an acceleration of 1 cm/s^2 in an object of mass 1 gram is called:
explanation: This is the definition of the dyne, the unit of force in the CGS system. 1 dyne = 1 g × 1 cm/s².

text: What is the relationship between 1 Newton (SI unit of force) and Dynes (CGS unit of force)?
explanation: 1 Newton = 1 kg × 1 m/s². Since 1 kg = 1000 g (10³ g) and 1 m = 100 cm (10² cm), then 1 N = (10³ g) × (10² cm/s²) = 10⁵ g cm/s². As 1 dyne = 1 g cm/s², it follows that 1 N = 10⁵ dyne.

text: According to the characteristics of action and reaction forces described by Newton's Third Law, which statement is INCORRECT?

options.text: They act on the same object, leading to equilibrium.

explanation: A fundamental characteristic of action and reaction forces is that they act on different objects. Therefore, they cannot cancel each other out on a single object to cause equilibrium of that object. They are equal in magnitude, opposite in direction, and act simultaneously.

text: The law of conservation of momentum is a direct consequence or corollary of which of Newton's laws of motion?

options.text: Newton's Second and Third Laws combined
It is an independent fundamental law.

explanation: The Law of Conservation of Momentum can be derived from Newton's Second Law (Force = rate of change of momentum) and Newton's Third Law (action-reaction forces are equal and opposite). For a system of interacting particles with no external forces, the internal action-reaction forces lead to the total momentum remaining constant.

text: In a collision between two isolated objects (no external forces), if the momentum of one object decreases by a certain amount, what happens to the momentum of the other object?

options.text: It also decreases by the same amount.
It increases by the same amount.

explanation: According to the Law of Conservation of Momentum, the total momentum of an isolated system remains constant. If the momentum of one object in the system decreases, the momentum of another object (or other objects) in the system must increase by an equivalent amount to ensure the total momentum is conserved.

text: When a net force is applied on an object in the direction of its existing velocity, its velocity will:
explanation: Applying a net force in the direction of an object's velocity causes positive acceleration in that same direction. This results in an increase in the magnitude of the velocity (i.e., the object speeds up).

text: When a net force is applied on an object opposite to the direction of its existing velocity, its velocity will primarily:

options.text: Become zero immediately regardless of force magnitude.

explanation: Applying a net force opposite to the direction of an object's velocity causes acceleration in the direction opposite to the velocity (negative acceleration or deceleration). This results in a decrease in the magnitude of the velocity (i.e., the object slows down).

text: An athlete completes a 400 m race on a circular track in 50 seconds. What is the athlete's average speed?
explanation: Average speed is calculated as the total distance travelled divided by the total time taken. Here, total distance = 400 m and total time = 50 s. So, Average Speed = 400 m / 50 s = 8 m/s.

text: An athlete runs around a 400m circular track and finishes at the starting point after 50 seconds. What is the athlete's average velocity for the entire run?
explanation: Average velocity is defined as total displacement divided by total time. Since the athlete starts and finishes at the same point on the circular track, the total displacement is zero. Therefore, the average velocity is 0 m / 50 s = 0 m/s.

text: An aeroplane taxies on the runway for 30 s with an acceleration of 3.2 m/s^2. If it is stated that it is 'starting from rest', what is its initial velocity?

options.text: Cannot be determined without final velocity.

explanation: When an object is described as 'starting from rest', it means its velocity at the beginning of the observed motion (its initial velocity, denoted by 'u') is 0 m/s.

text: A car starts from rest and accelerates uniformly at 2 m/s² for 10 seconds. How much distance does it cover in this time?
explanation: The distance covered (s) by an object undergoing uniform acceleration can be found using the equation s = ut + (1/2)at², where u is initial velocity, t is time, and a is acceleration. Here, u=0 m/s (starts from rest), a=2 m/s², and t=10 s. So, s = (0)(10) + (1/2)(2)(10)² = 0 + (1)(100) = 100 m.

text: When an object is thrown vertically upwards, what is its instantaneous vertical velocity at the highest point of its trajectory?

options.text: Equal to its initial upward velocity
Equal to the acceleration due to gravity

explanation: At the peak of its upward trajectory, an object thrown vertically upwards momentarily stops moving in the vertical direction before it begins to fall back down. At this precise instant, its instantaneous vertical velocity is 0 m/s, although it is still under the influence of gravitational acceleration.

text: An object is thrown upwards and reaches a maximum height 'h'. Its velocity at this maximum height is zero. If 'g' is the acceleration due to gravity (acting downwards), which equation of motion correctly relates its initial upward velocity 'u' to 'h' and 'g'?
explanation: We use the equation of motion v² = u² + 2as. Here, the final velocity 'v' at maximum height is 0. The displacement 's' is the height 'h'. The acceleration 'a' is -g (negative because gravity acts downwards, opposite to the initial upward velocity). So, 0² = u² + 2(-g)h, which simplifies to 0 = u² - 2gh, or u² = 2gh.

text: A motorboat starts from rest and moves with uniform acceleration. It attains a velocity of 15 m/s in 5 s. What is its acceleration?
explanation: Acceleration (a) can be calculated using the formula a = (v-u)/t, where 'v' is final velocity, 'u' is initial velocity, and 't' is time. Here, u=0 m/s (starts from rest), v=15 m/s, and t=5 s. So, a = (15 - 0) / 5 = 15 / 5 = 3 m/s².

text: A car accelerates uniformly from rest at an acceleration of 2 m/s² for 5 seconds. What distance does the car cover during this time?
explanation: The distance 's' covered can be found using the equation s = ut + 1/2 at². Given initial velocity u=0 (from rest), acceleration a=2 m/s², and time t=5 s. So, s = (0)(5) + 1/2 × (2) × (5)² = 0 + 1/2 × 2 × 25 = 1 × 25 = 25 m.

text: Why does an electric fan keep rotating for some time even after it is switched off and the electric power is cut?

options.text: Due to balanced forces continuing to act.
Due to the force of gravity on the blades.
Due to an unbalanced force from the motor still present.
Due to inertia of motion, which makes the blades resist stopping.

explanation: This phenomenon is due to inertia of motion, a concept from Newton's First Law. Once the fan blades are rotating, they possess inertia of motion and tend to continue rotating. They only slow down and stop due to opposing forces like air resistance and friction in the bearings.

text: It is easier to lift a small book from a table than to lift the entire heavy table. This difference in the effort required is primarily related to which property of the objects?

options.text: Their inertia, which is related to their mass
Their momentum while on the table

explanation: The difficulty in changing an object's state of rest (lifting it) is related to its inertia. Inertia is directly proportional to mass. The heavy table has a much larger mass and therefore greater inertia than the small book, requiring a larger force to overcome its inertia and lift it.

text: Consider a system consisting of a gun and a bullet. If both are initially at rest, what is the total momentum of the gun-bullet system before firing?

options.text: Equal to the mass of the bullet.
Equal to the mass of the gun.
Cannot be determined without knowing the bullet's potential velocity.

explanation: Momentum is the product of mass and velocity (P=mv). If an object is at rest, its velocity is zero, and therefore its momentum is zero. Since both the gun and the bullet are initially at rest, their individual momenta are zero, making the total momentum of the system zero before firing.

text: In the gun firing example, if the total momentum of the gun-bullet system before firing is zero, what must the total momentum of the gun and bullet be immediately after firing, according to the law of conservation of momentum (assuming no external forces)?

options.text: Greater than zero, in the direction of the bullet.
Less than zero (negative), if the gun's mass is large.
It depends on the speed of the bullet.

explanation: The Law of Conservation of Momentum states that if no net external force acts on a system, its total momentum remains constant. Since the total momentum of the gun-bullet system was zero before firing, it must also be zero immediately after firing. The bullet's forward momentum and the gun's backward (recoil) momentum will be equal in magnitude and opposite in direction, summing to zero.

text: The formula for gun recoil velocity (v_gun) can be expressed in terms of bullet velocity (v_bullet) and their masses (m_bullet, m_gun) as: m_gun * v_gun = - (m_bullet * v_bullet). What does the negative sign in this relationship signify?

options.text: The gun is decelerating after firing.
The bullet has negative momentum before firing.
The gun moves in the direction opposite to the bullet's motion.
The total momentum of the system is negative after firing.

explanation: In the conservation of momentum equation for gun recoil (where initial total momentum is zero), the negative sign indicates that the direction of the gun's velocity (recoil) is opposite to the direction of the bullet's velocity. If the bullet moves forward (positive velocity), the gun moves backward (negative velocity).

text: When two objects collide, and no net external forces are acting on the system of these two objects, their individual momenta may change, but their total momentum:

options.text: Is transferred entirely from the heavier object to the lighter one.

explanation: This is the core principle of the Law of Conservation of Momentum. In an isolated system (no net external forces), the total momentum of the system before a collision is equal to the total momentum of the system after the collision, even though the individual momenta of the colliding objects may change.

text: Imagine a marble released from rest and rolling down a gentle, straight, uniform slope on a flat surface. Neglecting friction and air resistance, its motion is likely to be:
explanation: As the marble rolls down a uniform slope, the component of gravitational force acting along the slope is constant. This constant net force (neglecting friction) will cause a constant acceleration according to Newton's Second Law. Since it moves in a straight line with constant acceleration, it's uniformly accelerated linear motion.

text: Consider a child on a swing. As the swing moves back and forth, its speed changes continuously (being zero at the highest points and maximum at the lowest point). Is the motion of the swing uniform or non-uniform?

options.text: Uniform, because it follows the same path repeatedly.
Non-uniform, because its speed changes throughout the swing.
Uniform, if the child does not pump their legs.
Non-uniform, only if an external push is applied.

explanation: The motion of a swing is non-uniform because its speed is constantly changing. It is slowest (momentarily zero) at the highest points of its arc and fastest at the lowest point. Since speed changes, the motion is non-uniform, and it is also accelerated.

text: A bullet of mass 10 g (0.01 kg) is fired from a gun of mass 1 kg. If the bullet moves with a speed of 300 m/s, what is the magnitude of the recoil velocity of the gun?
explanation: By conservation of momentum, (mass_bullet × velocity_bullet) + (mass_gun × velocity_gun) = 0. Let v_gun be recoil velocity. (0.01 kg)(300 m/s) + (1 kg)v_gun = 0. So, 3 kg m/s + (1 kg)v_gun = 0. This gives v_gun = -3 kg m/s / 1 kg = -3 m/s. The magnitude is 3 m/s.

text: If an object is thrown vertically upwards, its speed decreases as it goes up due to gravity. This decrease in speed while moving upwards is an example of:

options.text: Positive acceleration in the upward direction
Deceleration (or negative acceleration relative to upward motion)
Uniform velocity throughout the upward motion

explanation: When an object is thrown upwards, gravity exerts a constant downward force, causing a constant downward acceleration. Since this acceleration is opposite to the direction of upward motion, the object's upward speed decreases. This is known as deceleration or negative acceleration if the upward direction is considered positive.

text: The graphical method for deriving the equations of motion often uses a velocity-time graph. What physical quantity is typically plotted on the Y-axis (vertical axis) of this graph?
explanation: In a standard velocity-time graph used for analyzing motion and deriving equations of motion, velocity is plotted on the Y-axis (ordinate) and time is plotted on the X-axis (abscissa).

text: In the graphical derivation of the equation s = ut + 1/2 at² (displacement = initial velocity × time + half × acceleration × time squared), the displacement 's' is represented by the area under the velocity-time graph. If the initial velocity 'u' is non-zero and there's uniform acceleration 'a', this area can be visualized as the sum of which two basic geometric shapes?
explanation: On a velocity-time graph for uniform acceleration with initial velocity 'u', the area under the graph for time 't' forms a trapezium. This trapezium can be divided into a rectangle (base 't', height 'u', area 'ut') and a triangle (base 't', height 'at' which is v-u, area '1/2 × t × at = 1/2 at²'). The sum gives s = ut + 1/2 at².

text: In a standard velocity-time graph used to derive equations of motion, what does the length of the segment along the time-axis (horizontal X-axis) typically represent for the duration of motion being analyzed?
explanation: The horizontal axis (X-axis) in a velocity-time graph represents time. A segment along this axis from the origin (t=0) to a point 't' represents the time interval over which the motion is considered.

text: On a velocity-time graph, what does the intercept on the velocity-axis (vertical Y-axis) at the point where time t=0 represent?
explanation: The Y-intercept of a velocity-time graph is the value of velocity when time (the X-axis value) is zero. This corresponds to the velocity of the object at the beginning of the observation period, which is defined as the initial velocity (u).

text: On a velocity-time graph for uniformly accelerated motion, what does the velocity value corresponding to the final time 't' of the motion represent?
explanation: If a period of motion is considered over a time interval from t=0 to a final time 't', the velocity of the object at this final time 't' is known as its final velocity (v). This is represented by the Y-coordinate on the graph at that specific X-coordinate 't'.

text: In uniform circular motion, the acceleration is directed towards the center of the circle (centripetal acceleration). This acceleration is primarily due to the continuous change in:

options.text: The direction of the object's velocity
The magnitude of the centripetal force

explanation: In uniform circular motion, the speed of the object is constant, but its velocity is continuously changing because its direction of motion is continuously changing. Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity. The centripetal acceleration, directed towards the center, arises from this continuous change in the direction of the velocity vector.

text: A satellite moving around the Earth in a stable circular orbit at a constant speed is an example of:
explanation: Uniform circular motion is defined as the motion of an object traveling at a constant (uniform) speed along a circular path. A satellite in a stable circular orbit maintains a constant speed, thus fitting this definition.

text: If an object is dropped and falls freely towards the ground, neglecting air resistance, its motion is characterized by:
explanation: Objects in free fall (where only gravity acts, and air resistance is neglected) experience a constant downward acceleration due to gravity, typically denoted as 'g' (approximately 9.8 m/s² near Earth's surface). This is an example of uniformly accelerated motion.

text: In the analysis of an object in free fall, if the ground level is taken as the reference point for zero height, what is the value of its gravitational potential energy when the object reaches the ground?

options.text: Equal to its kinetic energy at that point
Equal to its total mechanical energy

explanation: Gravitational potential energy (P.E.) is given by the formula P.E. = mgh, where 'm' is mass, 'g' is acceleration due to gravity, and 'h' is the height above a reference level. If the ground is chosen as the reference level where h=0, then the potential energy of the object upon reaching the ground is m × g × 0 = 0.

text: According to the principle of conservation of mechanical energy, what happens to the total energy (Kinetic Energy + Potential Energy) of an object in free fall, assuming air resistance is negligible?

options.text: Total mechanical energy decreases as it falls.
Total mechanical energy increases as it falls.
Total mechanical energy is converted entirely to heat upon impact.
Total mechanical energy remains constant at all points during the fall.

explanation: In the absence of non-conservative forces like air resistance, the total mechanical energy (sum of kinetic energy and potential energy) of a freely falling object is conserved. As the object falls, its potential energy decreases (as height decreases) while its kinetic energy increases (as speed increases), but their sum remains constant.

text: If an object is thrown vertically upwards, what is the direction of the gravitational acceleration acting on it throughout its upward and downward motion (neglecting air resistance)?

options.text: Upwards during upward motion, downwards during downward motion.
Downwards, consistently throughout the entire motion.
Zero at the highest point, then downwards.
It changes direction depending on the object's velocity.

explanation: The acceleration due to gravity always acts downwards towards the center of the Earth, regardless of the direction of the object's motion. So, whether the object is moving upwards, is momentarily at its highest point, or is falling downwards, the gravitational acceleration is constant and directed downwards (assuming air resistance is negligible and it's close to Earth's surface).

text: In a tug-of-war, if the forces applied by the two opposing teams become unequal, what happens to the center of the rope?

options.text: It remains static due to inertia.
It accelerates and shifts in the direction of the greater applied force.
It accelerates and shifts in the direction of the smaller applied force.
The rope is likely to break immediately.

explanation: When the forces applied by the two teams in a tug-of-war are unequal, there is a net unbalanced force acting on the rope. According to Newton's Second Law, this net force will cause the rope (and its center) to accelerate in the direction of the stronger force.

text: A net force 'F' acts on an object of mass 'm' causing an acceleration 'a'. According to Newton's Second Law (F=ma), if the applied net force is doubled while the mass of the object is kept constant, the new acceleration will be:

options.text: The same as the original acceleration (a).

explanation: Newton's Second Law states F = ma. If mass 'm' is constant, then acceleration 'a' is directly proportional to the net force 'F'. If the force is doubled (becomes 2F), then the new acceleration will also be doubled (2a), because (2F) = m(2a).

text: A net force 'F' acts on an object of mass 'm' causing an acceleration 'a'. If the mass 'm' of the object is doubled (to 2m) while the applied net force 'F' is kept constant, the new acceleration will be:

options.text: The same as the original acceleration (a).

explanation: Newton's Second Law states F = ma, which can be rearranged to a = F/m. If the net force 'F' is constant, then acceleration 'a' is inversely proportional to the mass 'm'. If the mass is doubled (becomes 2m), then the new acceleration will be halved (a/2), because a_new = F/(2m) = (1/2)(F/m) = a/2.

text: When you push against a wall, you feel the wall pushing back on you. This pair of forces is an illustration of which of Newton's laws?
explanation: This scenario is a classic example of Newton's Third Law of Motion. Your push on the wall is the 'action' force, and the wall's push back on you is the 'reaction' force. These forces are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction, acting on different objects (you and the wall).

text: Why is it generally more difficult and potentially more painful to catch a hard cricket ball travelling at a high speed compared to a lighter tennis ball moving at the same high speed?

options.text: The cricket ball has less inertia and is harder to control.
The cricket ball has significantly greater mass, thus greater momentum, requiring a larger impulse to stop.
The cricket ball experiences less air resistance, so it maintains its speed better.
The tennis ball has greater momentum due to its bounciness.

explanation: The difficulty in stopping an object depends on its momentum (mass × velocity). A cricket ball has a significantly larger mass than a tennis ball. If both are moving at the same high speed, the cricket ball will have much greater momentum. To stop it, a larger change in momentum (impulse) is required over the same time, or the same impulse over a shorter time, resulting in a larger average force experienced by the catcher.

text: If an object is thrown vertically upwards and reaches its highest point before falling back, what is its instantaneous vertical velocity at that highest point?

options.text: Equal to the acceleration due to gravity

explanation: At the very peak of its upward trajectory, an object thrown vertically upwards momentarily stops its upward motion before it begins to descend. At this instant, its vertical velocity is zero, even though it is still under the influence of gravity (and thus accelerating downwards).

text: An object moves along a straight path, covering 18 m in the first 3 seconds, then 22 m in the next 3 seconds, and finally 14 m in the last 3 seconds. What type of motion is this?
explanation: The object covers different distances (18m, 22m, 14m) in equal consecutive time intervals (3s each). Since the distance covered per unit time (speed) is not constant, the motion is non-uniform. More specifically, it has non-uniform speed.

text: An object moves for 5 seconds, then for another 10 seconds, and finally for 7 seconds. What is the total duration of its motion?

options.text: Can't be determined without knowing speeds.

explanation: The total time taken for the motion is simply the sum of the individual time intervals during which the object moved. Total time = 5 s + 10 s + 7 s = 22 s.

text: A person walks 50 m East, then 30 m West, and finally 20 m East. What is the total distance covered by the person?
explanation: Total distance is the sum of the lengths of all segments of the path travelled, regardless of direction. In this case, total distance = 50 m + 30 m + 20 m = 100 m.

text: A car travels 60 km in the first hour and 90 km in the next two hours. What is its average speed for the entire 3-hour journey?
explanation: Average speed is calculated as the total distance travelled divided by the total time taken. Total distance = 60 km + 90 km = 150 km. Total time = 1 hour + 2 hours = 3 hours. Therefore, Average speed = 150 km / 3 hours = 50 km/h.

text: An object of mass 16 kg is moving with an acceleration of 3 m/s^2. What is the magnitude of the net force acting on the object?
explanation: According to Newton's Second Law of Motion, Force (F) = mass (m) × acceleration (a). Given mass m = 16 kg and acceleration a = 3 m/s², the net force F = 16 kg × 3 m/s² = 48 N.

text: A net force of 100 N is applied to an object of mass 20 kg. What is the acceleration produced in the object?
explanation: According to Newton's second law, Force (F) = mass (m) × acceleration (a). This can be rearranged to find acceleration: a = F/m. Given F = 100 N and m = 20 kg, the acceleration a = 100 N / 20 kg = 5 m/s².

text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding balanced forces acting on an object?

options.text: They always cause a change in the state of motion of an object.
The net force resulting from them is non-zero.
They result in a net force of zero, causing no change in the object's state of motion.
They always cause the object to accelerate uniformly.

explanation: Balanced forces are two or more forces acting on an object that are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction. Their combined effect (net force) is zero. According to Newton's First Law, a zero net force means there will be no change in the object's state of motion (it will remain at rest if initially at rest, or continue moving with constant velocity if initially in motion).

text: Why is a thick bed of sand or a soft mat used for high jumpers to land on during competitions?

options.text: To increase the total change in momentum during landing.
To decrease the total change in momentum during landing.
To increase the time taken for the jumper to come to rest, thereby reducing the impact force.
To decrease the time taken for the jumper to come to rest, thereby increasing the jump height.

explanation: When a high jumper lands, their momentum must be reduced to zero. The change in momentum (impulse) is equal to Force × Time (FΔt = Δp). A soft landing surface like sand or a mat deforms upon impact, increasing the time interval (Δt) over which the jumper's momentum changes. For a given change in momentum, increasing the time of impact reduces the average force (F = Δp/Δt) exerted on the jumper, making the landing safer and less injurious.

text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of action and reaction forces as described by Newton's Third Law?

options.text: They act on the same object and thus cancel each other out.

explanation: Action and reaction forces, according to Newton's Third Law, are always equal in magnitude and opposite in direction. Crucially, they act on different objects. Because they act on different objects, they do not cancel each other's effect on any single object. For example, if object A pushes object B, object B pushes back on object A.

text: When an object is moving in uniform circular motion, the net force acting on it, known as the centripetal force, is directed:

options.text: Tangentially, in the direction of instantaneous velocity.
Towards the center of the circular path.
Away from the center of the circular path (radially outward).
Zero, because the speed is constant.

explanation: For an object to move in a circular path, even at constant speed (uniform circular motion), there must be a net force acting on it to continuously change its direction of velocity. This net force, called the centripetal force, is always directed towards the center of the circle. It causes the centripetal acceleration.

text: If an object starts from rest and accelerates uniformly in a straight line, which of the following statements about its motion is FALSE?

options.text: Its speed increases linearly with time (v ∝ t).
Its velocity increases linearly with time.
The distance covered is proportional to the square of the time (s ∝ t²).
Its acceleration changes linearly with time.

explanation: Uniform acceleration means the acceleration itself is constant; it does not change with time. If starting from rest (u=0): 1. Velocity v = at, so velocity (and speed) increases linearly with time. 2. Distance s = (1/2)at², so distance is proportional to the square of time. The statement that acceleration changes linearly with time is false for uniform acceleration.

text: Consider an object moving with uniform velocity. Its acceleration is zero. What does this imply about the net external force acting on the object?

options.text: The net force is constant and in the direction of motion.
The net force is constant and opposite to the direction of motion.
The net force must be gravitational.

explanation: According to Newton's Second Law of Motion (F_net = ma), if the acceleration (a) of an object is zero (which is the case for uniform velocity), then the net external force (F_net) acting on the object must also be zero. This is consistent with Newton's First Law.

text: The statement "Every action force has an equal and opposite reaction force which acts simultaneously" is:

options.text: The Law of Conservation of Momentum

explanation: This is the direct statement of Newton's Third Law (Page 24).

text: A heavy truck and a light car are both moving with the same kinetic energy. If they are stopped by applying the same braking force, which vehicle will travel a shorter distance before stopping?

options.text: Both will travel the same distance
It depends on the coefficient of friction.

explanation: This problem requires applying the Work-Energy theorem (covered in Chapter 2, but based on force and distance from Chapter 1). Work done by the braking force (F * distance) equals the change in kinetic energy (which is equal to the initial KE since the final KE is zero). If the initial kinetic energy is the same for both, and the braking force is the same, then the stopping distance (distance = KE / Force) must be the same for both vehicles.

text: When is work said to be done, according to physics?

options.text: When an object is at rest.
When a force is applied, regardless of displacement.
When a force applied on an object causes displacement of the object.

explanation: In physics, work is said to be done when a force applied on an object causes displacement of the object. (Page 28)

text: What is the formula for calculating work done when the force and displacement are in the same direction?
explanation: The work done by a force acting on an object is the product of the magnitude of the force and the displacement of the object in the direction of the force. Thus, Work = Force × displacement. (Page 28)

text: If a child pulls a toy cart with a string, and the string makes an angle θ with the horizontal, the work done is given by:
explanation: When the applied force (F) makes an angle θ with the direction of displacement (s), the component of force in the direction of displacement is F cos θ. Thus, work done W = (F cos θ) s = F s cos θ. (Page 29)

text: The SI unit of work is:
explanation: In the SI system, the unit of force is newton (N) and the unit of displacement is metre (m). Thus, the unit of work is newton-metre, which is called Joule (J). (Page 30)

text: How is 1 Joule of work defined?

options.text: If a force of 1 dyne displaces an object by 1 cm.
If a force of 1 Newton displaces an object by 1 cm.
If a force of 1 Newton displaces an object by 1 metre in the direction of the force.
If a force of 1 dyne displaces an object by 1 metre.

explanation: 1 Joule is defined as the work done when a force of 1 newton displaces an object through 1 metre in the direction of the force. (Page 30)

text: What is the CGS unit of work?
explanation: In the CGS system, the unit of force is dyne and that of displacement is centimeter (cm). Thus, the unit of work done is dyne-centimetre, which is called an erg. (Page 30)

text: What is the relationship between Joule and erg?
explanation: We know that 1 newton = 10^5 dyne and 1 m = 10^2 cm. Therefore, 1 Joule = 1 N × 1 m = (10^5 dyne) × (10^2 cm) = 10^7 dyne cm = 10^7 erg. (Page 30)

text: When is the work done by a force considered positive?

options.text: When the force and displacement are in opposite directions.
When the force and displacement are perpendicular to each other.
When the force and displacement are in the same direction.

explanation: When the force and the displacement are in the same direction (θ = 0°), the work done by the force is positive. (Page 30)

text: If a person pushes against a stationary wall, the work done is:
explanation: Work is done when a force causes displacement. If the wall is stationary, there is no displacement (s=0), so the work done is zero, even though force is applied. (Page 30)

text: When is the work done by a force considered negative?

options.text: When the force and displacement are in the same direction.
When the force and displacement are in opposite directions.
When the force and displacement are perpendicular to each other.

explanation: When the force and the displacement are in opposite directions (θ = 180°), the work done by the force is negative. (Page 30)

text: The work done by the gravitational force on an artificial satellite moving around the Earth in a circular orbit is:
explanation: For an artificial satellite in a circular orbit, the gravitational force is directed towards the center of the Earth (along the radius), and its displacement at any instant is along the tangent to the circle. Since the force and displacement are perpendicular to each other (θ = 90°), the work done by the gravitational force is zero. (Page 31)

text: What is defined as 'the capacity of a body to perform work'?
explanation: The capacity of a body to perform work is called its energy. (Page 32)

text: Which of the following is NOT a form of mechanical energy?

options.text: Both kinetic and potential energy are mechanical

explanation: Mechanical energy includes potential energy and kinetic energy. Heat energy is a different form of energy. (Page 32)

text: The energy which an object has because of its motion is called:
explanation: The energy which an object has because of its motion is called its kinetic energy. (Page 32)

text: What is the formula for kinetic energy (K.E.)?
explanation: The formula for kinetic energy is K.E. = (1/2)mv², where m is the mass of the object and v is its velocity. (Page 33)

text: If the velocity of an object is doubled, its kinetic energy becomes:
explanation: Kinetic energy is proportional to the square of the velocity (K.E. ∝ v²). If velocity is doubled (2v), then K.E. becomes (2v)² = 4v², which is four times the original. (Page 33)

text: The energy stored in an object because of its specific state or position is called:
explanation: The energy stored in an object because of its specific state or position is called its potential energy. (Page 34)

text: The formula for gravitational potential energy is:
explanation: The amount of potential energy stored in an object of mass 'm' at a height 'h' above the Earth's surface is P.E. = mgh, where 'g' is the acceleration due to gravity. (Page 34)

text: If an object of mass 5 kg is lifted to a height of 4 m, what is its potential energy? (Assume g = 10 m/s²)
explanation: Potential Energy (P.E.) = mgh = 5 kg × 10 m/s² × 4 m = 200 J. (Page 34)

text: Potential energy is a relative quantity. This means its value depends on the:

options.text: Choice of the reference level (zero height)

explanation: Potential energy is relative. The height 'h' in mgh is measured from a reference level. If the reference level changes, the potential energy value changes. The Ajay and Atul example illustrates this. (Page 34)

text: Which principle states that 'Energy can neither be created nor destroyed. It can be converted from one form into another'?
explanation: This is the statement of the Law of Conservation of Energy. (Page 35)

text: In a coupled pendulum system where one pendulum transfers its energy to another, this demonstrates:
explanation: The coupled oscillators (pendulums) example shows that one pendulum transfers its energy to the other, illustrating the transformation and transfer of energy, consistent with the law of conservation of energy. (Page 35)

text: An object falling solely under the influence of gravitational force is said to be in:
explanation: An object falling solely under the influence of gravitational force is said to be in free fall or to be falling freely. (Page 36)

text: During the free fall of an object, its total mechanical energy (K.E. + P.E.):
explanation: During free fall, potential energy gets converted to kinetic energy, but the total mechanical energy (sum of P.E. and K.E.) remains constant, assuming no air resistance. (Page 36)

text: An object is dropped from a height 'h'. When it reaches the ground, its potential energy is ____ and its kinetic energy is ____ (assuming ground as reference).
explanation: When the object reaches the ground (height = 0), its potential energy becomes zero. By the law of conservation of energy, its initial potential energy (mgh) is converted into kinetic energy. So K.E. = mgh at the ground. (Page 36, point C)

text: What is defined as 'the rate at which work is done'?
explanation: Power is the rate at which work is done. (Page 37)

text: The SI unit of power is:
explanation: In the SI system, the unit of work is J, so the unit of power is J/s. This is called watt (W). (Page 37)

text: 1 watt is equal to:
explanation: 1 watt = 1 joule / 1 second. (Page 37)

text: One horsepower (hp) is approximately equal to:
explanation: In the industrial sector, the unit used to measure power is called ‘horse power.’ 1 horse power = 746 watt. (Page 37)

text: The commercial unit of energy is:
explanation: The unit of energy for commercial use is kilo watt hour (kWh). (Page 37)

text: 1 kilowatt-hour (kWh) is equal to:
A coolie lifts a luggage of 15 kg from the ground and puts it on his head 1.5 m above the ground. Calculate the work done by him on the luggage. (g = 10 m/s²)
explanation: Work done = Force × displacement = (mass × g) × height = (15 kg × 10 m/s²) × 1.5 m = 150 N × 1.5 m = 225 J. (Page 28, similar to PE concept on Page 34)

text: If the angle between the force and displacement is 60°, and the force is 10 N and displacement is 2 m, the work done is: (cos 60° = 0.5)
explanation: Work done W = F s cos θ = 10 N × 2 m × cos 60° = 10 N × 2 m × 0.5 = 10 J. (Page 29)

text: A car of mass 1000 kg is moving with a velocity of 10 m/s. Its kinetic energy is:
An electric motor does 600 J of work in 10 seconds. What is its power?
explanation: Power (P) = Work (W) / Time (t) = 600 J / 10 s = 60 W. (Page 37)

text: Swaralee takes 20 s to carry a bag weighing 20 kg to a height of 5 m. What is the work done by Swaralee? (g = 9.8 m/s²)
explanation: Work done W = Force × displacement = (mg) × h = (20 kg × 9.8 m/s²) × 5 m = 196 N × 5 m = 980 J. This is directly from a solved example. (Page 38)

text: In the example where Swaralee does 980 J of work in 20 s, what is her power output?
explanation: Power = Work / Time = 980 J / 20 s = 49 W. (The textbook example states 40s for time for a power of 24.5W. Here using the provided time of 20s from the previous question's context, if we take the work as 980 J, power is 49W. The textbook example has time t=40s for power to be 24.5W. The question refers to the values given in example but with time as 20s) The original question in PDF text (pg 38) says t=40s, but the question implies using the values from example where work is 980J. If t=20s, P = 980/20 = 49W. If t=40s (as per book for 24.5W), P = 980/40 = 24.5W. Assuming this refers to textbook values: Work 980J, Time 40s, P=24.5W. But if it means *her* power using the 20s *from the prior question*, then it is 49W. Let's use the time from the question itself.

text: A 25 W electric bulb is used for 10 hours every day. How much electrical energy does it consume in one day?
explanation: Power P = 25 W = 0.025 kW. Time t = 10 hours. Energy consumed = Power × Time = 0.025 kW × 10 hr = 0.25 kWh. (Page 38)

text: If an object's mass is doubled and its velocity is also doubled, its kinetic energy will increase by a factor of:
explanation: Original K.E. = (1/2)mv². New mass m' = 2m, new velocity v' = 2v. New K.E.' = (1/2)(2m)(2v)² = (1/2)(2m)(4v²) = 8 × (1/2)mv² = 8 × K.E. So it increases by a factor of 8. (Page 33)

text: An object of mass 'm' is at a height 'h'. If it is lifted to a height '2h', its potential energy becomes:
explanation: Potential energy P.E. = mgh. If height becomes 2h, new P.E.' = mg(2h) = 2(mgh) = 2 × P.E. So it becomes double. (Page 34)

text: Work done is a scalar quantity because:

options.text: It is the product of two vector quantities.
It is the dot product of force and displacement, which results in a scalar.
It always has a positive value.
It only has direction, no magnitude.

explanation: Work done is defined as the dot product of force and displacement vectors (W = F ⋅ s = Fs cos θ). The dot product of two vectors is a scalar quantity, meaning it has magnitude but no direction. (Related to concepts on Page 29).

text: Which of these is an example of energy transformation from chemical energy to light and heat energy?
explanation: Burning a candle involves a chemical reaction (combustion of wax) that releases energy in the form of light and heat. (Page 35 describes energy transformation).

text: A body is thrown vertically upwards. Its total mechanical energy during its flight (neglecting air resistance):

options.text: Is maximum at the highest point.
Is maximum at the point of projection.

explanation: According to the law of conservation of energy, if air resistance is neglected, the total mechanical energy (sum of kinetic and potential energy) of the body remains constant throughout its flight. (Similar to free fall concept, Page 36).

text: If a force of 50 N acts on an object and displaces it by 4 m at an angle of 0 degrees with the force, the work done is:
explanation: Work done W = F s cos θ. Here F = 50 N, s = 4 m, θ = 0°. cos 0° = 1. So, W = 50 × 4 × 1 = 200 J. (Page 29)

text: The energy possessed by a compressed spring is an example of:
explanation: A compressed spring stores energy due to its deformed state. This is known as elastic potential energy. (Page 34 mentions potential energy due to specific state or position; a compressed spring is an example of this state).

text: Two objects of masses m1 and m2 have equal kinetic energies. If their velocities are v1 and v2 respectively, then the ratio v1/v2 is:
explanation: Given (1/2)m1v1² = (1/2)m2v2². So, m1v1² = m2v2². Then v1²/v2² = m2/m1. Therefore, v1/v2 = √(m2/m1). (Based on KE formula, Page 33)

text: A man climbs a staircase of height 10 m. If his mass is 60 kg and g = 9.8 m/s², the work done by him against gravity is:
explanation: Work done against gravity = Potential energy gained = mgh = 60 kg × 9.8 m/s² × 10 m = 5880 J. (Page 34)

text: If a body does 100 J of work in 5 seconds, what is its power?
explanation: Power = Work / Time = 100 J / 5 s = 20 W. (Page 37)

text: The unit of energy in SI system is Joule, and in CGS system it is erg. The units of work and energy are:
explanation: The units of work and energy are the same. The unit in SI system is joule while that in cgs system is erg. (Page 32)

text: When a fast cricket ball strikes the stumps, what type of energy does the ball primarily possess that causes the stumps to move?
explanation: A moving object, like a fast cricket ball, possesses kinetic energy due to its motion. This kinetic energy is transferred to the stumps upon impact, causing them to move. (Page 32)

text: An object is at rest. What is its kinetic energy?
explanation: Kinetic energy K.E. = (1/2)mv². If the object is at rest, its velocity v = 0. Therefore, K.E. = (1/2)m(0)² = 0. (Page 33)

text: If a force applied on an object is perpendicular to its displacement, the work done is:
explanation: Work done W = F s cos θ. If force and displacement are perpendicular, θ = 90°. Since cos 90° = 0, the work done is zero. (Page 30)

text: Consider two objects, A and B. Object A has mass 'm' and is at height '2h'. Object B has mass '2m' and is at height 'h'. What is the ratio of their potential energies (P.E._A / P.E._B)?
explanation: P.E._A = m * g * (2h) = 2mgh. P.E._B = (2m) * g * h = 2mgh. So, P.E._A / P.E._B = 2mgh / 2mgh = 1/1 or 1:1. (Page 34)

text: In a hydroelectric power plant, the potential energy of stored water is converted into:
explanation: In a hydroelectric power plant, the potential energy of water stored at a height is first converted into kinetic energy as it falls, which then rotates turbines to generate electrical energy. (Relates to energy transformation, Page 35).

text: An object in free fall has its potential energy decreasing and kinetic energy increasing. At any point, the sum of K.E. and P.E. (ignoring air resistance):
explanation: This is a direct application of the Law of Conservation of Mechanical Energy during free fall. The total mechanical energy (K.E. + P.E.) remains constant. (Page 36)

text: If an agent's power is 500 W, how much work can it do in 2 minutes?
explanation: Power P = Work W / Time t. So, W = P × t. Time = 2 minutes = 2 × 60 seconds = 120 seconds. Work W = 500 W × 120 s = 60,000 J. (Page 37)

text: Which of the following units represents energy?
explanation: Kilowatt-hour (kWh) is a unit of energy (Power × Time). Kilowatt is a unit of power. (Page 37)

text: The work done in lifting an object depends on the path taken.

options.text: False, work done against gravity depends only on vertical displacement.
False, it depends on the speed of lifting.

explanation: Work done by a conservative force like gravity is path-independent and depends only on the initial and final positions (specifically, the vertical displacement). (Related to PE=mgh concept, Page 34)

text: A stone of mass 0.25 kg is falling from a height. Its kinetic energy when its velocity is 2 m/s is:
explanation: K.E. = (1/2)mv² = (1/2) × 0.25 kg × (2 m/s)² = (1/2) × 0.25 × 4 = 0.5 J. (From solved example on Page 33)

text: If the force and displacement are in the same direction, the angle θ in W = Fs cos θ is:
explanation: When force and displacement are in the same direction, the angle between them is 0°. (Page 30)

text: Pravin applied a force of 100 N on an object at an angle of 60° to the horizontal. If 400 J of work was done and the object displaced horizontally, what was the displacement? (cos 60° = 1/2)
explanation: W = Fs cos θ. So, 400 J = 100 N × s × (1/2). 400 = 50s. s = 400/50 = 8 m. (From solved example on Page 32)

text: The scientist James Watt is associated with the unit of:
explanation: The unit of power is called Watt in honour of the Scottish scientist James Watt. (Page 37)

text: An object is dropped from rest. At the moment of release, its kinetic energy is ____ and its potential energy is ____ (relative to the ground).
explanation: When an object is dropped from rest, its initial velocity is zero, so its kinetic energy is zero. Its potential energy is maximum at the highest point (moment of release). (Page 36, point A)

text: If work is done at a faster rate, then:
explanation: Power is the rate of doing work (P=W/t). If work is done faster (less time for the same work, or more work in the same time), the power is greater. (Page 37)

text: When a body falls from a height, its potential energy is converted into kinetic energy. This is an example of:
explanation: The conversion of potential energy to kinetic energy as a body falls is a classic example of energy transformation. (Page 35, also implied in free fall section Page 36)

text: Which of the following is a unit of energy but NOT a unit of power?
explanation: Joule is a unit of energy (and work). Watt, kilowatt, and horsepower are units of power. (Pages 30, 32, 37)

text: If the work done by a force is zero, it implies that:

options.text: The angle between force and displacement is 90°.
Any of the above (a, b, or c) or a combination could be true.

explanation: Work done (W = Fs cos θ) is zero if F=0, or s=0, or cos θ = 0 (i.e., θ=90°). So any of these conditions will result in zero work. (Page 30)

text: The kinetic energy of an object depends on its:
explanation: Kinetic energy K.E. = (1/2)mv². It depends on the mass (m) and velocity (v) of the object. (Page 33)

text: A body of mass 2 kg is dropped from a height of 10 m. Its potential energy just before hitting the ground is (assuming g = 9.8 m/s² and ground as reference):
explanation: Just before hitting the ground, the height (h) is approximately zero relative to the ground. Therefore, its potential energy P.E. = mgh = 2 kg × 9.8 m/s² × 0 m = 0 J. (Page 34, Page 36 point C)

text: When an arrow is released from a stretched bow, the potential energy of the bow is converted into:
explanation: A stretched bow possesses elastic potential energy. When the arrow is released, this potential energy is converted into the kinetic energy of the arrow. (Page 34 refers to PE, Page 35 to transformation)

text: Which of the following does not affect the potential energy of an object at a certain height?
explanation: Gravitational potential energy (P.E. = mgh) depends on mass (m), height (h), and acceleration due to gravity (g). The horizontal velocity does not affect its gravitational potential energy. (Page 34)

text: Power can also be expressed as the product of:

options.text: Force and velocity (if force is constant and in direction of velocity)

explanation: Power P = W/t = (Fs)/t. If velocity v = s/t is constant, then P = Fv. This is an extension of the power concept. (Related to Page 37)

text: The work done by friction is generally:
explanation: The force of friction always opposes motion (or tendency of motion). Thus, the displacement is in the opposite direction to the frictional force, making the work done by friction negative (cos 180° = -1). (Related to concept of negative work, Page 30)
