text: The 'Local Group' refers to:

options.text: A cluster of stars within the Milky Way.
The planets of our solar system.
A group of galaxies of which the Milky Way is a part.
A collection of comets and asteroids.

explanation: The Milky Way is a part of the ‘Local Group’ of galaxies. (Page 112)

text: Which planet rotates around itself from east to west, unlike most other planets?
explanation: Venus: It rotates around itself from east to west. (Page 115)

text: The phenomenon where the Moon passes directly between the Sun and Earth, casting a shadow on Earth, is called a:
explanation: A solar eclipse occurs when the Moon is positioned between the Sun and Earth, blocking sunlight and casting a shadow on Earth. (Out of PDF, but related to celestial bodies and shadows, mentioned as phenomenon to study in 'Always remember...' on page 118).

text: What is a light-year?

options.text: The time it takes for light to travel from the Sun to Earth.
The distance light travels in one year.
A unit of time equal to 365.25 days.
The brightness of a star as seen from Earth.

explanation: A light-year is a unit of astronomical distance equivalent to the distance that light travels in one year. (Out of PDF, but fundamental for discussing distances in the universe).

text: The Big Bang Theory is the prevailing cosmological model for:
explanation: The Big Bang Theory describes the origin and evolution of the universe from an extremely hot, dense state. (Out of PDF, but a foundational concept in cosmology).

text: Olympus Mons, the highest and longest mountain in the solar system, is located on:
explanation: The highest and longest mountain in the solar system ‘Olympus Mons’ is located on Mars. (Page 115)

text: Which type of stars are even brighter and larger than red giant stars, with diameters more than a hundred times greater than the Sun?
explanation: Super Nova: These are even brighter and larger than the red giant stars. Their diameter can be more than a hundred times greater than that of the Sun. (Page 113)

text: The Sun rotates around its axis and also revolves around:

options.text: The center of the Milky Way galaxy

explanation: The sun rotates around its axis and while doing so, it revolves around the centre of the Milky Way taking the solar system along with it. (Page 114)

text: Which planet is known for having winds that blow with extremely high speed and where a season lasts for about 41 years?
explanation: Neptune: A season on Neptune lasts for about 41 years. On this planet winds blow with extremely high speed. (Page 115)

text: If a meteor does not completely burn up in the atmosphere and falls to the surface of the Earth, it is called a:
explanation: Sometimes the meteors do not burn completely and fall to the surface of the earth. These are called meteorites. (Page 117)

text: What is the primary reason we only see one side of the Moon from Earth?

options.text: The other side is always dark.
The Moon does not rotate on its axis.
The Moon's period of rotation is the same as its period of revolution around Earth (synchronous rotation).
Earth's atmosphere blocks the view of the other side.

explanation: The Moon is tidally locked with Earth, meaning its rotation period matches its orbital period (27.3 days as per Page 116), so the same side always faces Earth. (Page 116 Q1)

text: Short-period comets are those that take less than how many years to complete one revolution around the sun?
explanation: Short period comets: These comets take less than 200 years to complete one revolution around the sun. (Page 116)

text: The Pole Star (Polaris) is given as an example of which type of star?
explanation: Variable Stars: For example, Polaris (Pole Star). (Page 113)

text: Which planet has the largest number of known satellites listed in the table?
explanation: According to the table on page 114, Jupiter has 64 known satellites, which is the highest number listed. (Page 114)

text: Fred Whipple proposed that comets consist of an icy cluster, leading them to be called:
explanation: Fred Whipple proposed that comets consist of an icy cluster of various constituents. That is why, comets came to be called ‘dirty snowballs’. (Page 117)

text: A constellation is a:

options.text: Group of stars forming a recognizable pattern in the sky.
Cloud of gas and dust where stars are born.

explanation: A constellation is a group of stars that appear to form a pattern or picture in the sky. (Out of PDF, but related to stars and sky observation)

text: What is a black hole?

options.text: A hole in a planet's surface.
A region in space where gravity is so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape.

explanation: A black hole is a region of spacetime where gravity is so strong that nothing—no particles or even electromagnetic radiation such as light—can escape from it. (Out of PDF, but related to advanced celestial concepts and 'dead stars' mentioned on Page 112)

text: The study of celestial objects, space, and the physical universe as a whole is called:
explanation: Astronomy is the scientific study of celestial objects (such as stars, planets, comets, and galaxies) and phenomena that originate outside the Earth's atmosphere. (Out of PDF, the whole chapter is about astronomy)

text: Which of the following is the largest planet in our solar system?
explanation: Jupiter: This is the largest planet of the solar system. (Page 115)

text: The Earth's magnetic field is important because it:

options.text: Diverts harmful solar radiation towards the polar regions.

explanation: As the earth is a magnet, there is a magnetic field around the earth. It diverts the harmful rays from the sun towards the polar regions of the earth. (Page 115)
